text:
Perhaps basic, but how can I make this work?
```function foo(x)
           for i in x
               println(i)
           end
           isodd(i) && println("Last is odd")
       end```

elements.text: Perhaps basic, but how can I make this work?

function foo(x)
           for i in x
               println(i)
           end
           isodd(i) && println("Last is odd")
       end

text:
```julia> function foo(x)
           i = 0
           for outer i in x
               println(i)
           end
           isodd(i) && println("Last is odd")
       end
foo (generic function with 1 method)

julia> foo(1:4)
1
2
3
4
false

julia> foo(1:3)
1
2
3
Last is odd```

Last is odd```

text:
you can also just do
```isodd(x[end]) && println("Last is odd")```
that only works when `x` is indexable, which not all iterables are

elements.text: is indexable, which not all iterables are

text: `last(x)`
or is that the same
My original question was just about how to use a loop variable in the function's local scope outside the loop, the function was just a simple example :)

elements.text: My original question was just about how to use a loop variable in the function's local scope outside the loop, the function was just a simple example :)

text: the `last(x)` works in this case where the loop has a defined end, but you could also have `x = repeated(1)` (which generates `1` forever), and break out at some iteration - in that case `last(x)` doesn't work, but the last iteration still has meaning :)

elements.text: works in this case where the loop has a defined end, but you could also have
forever), and break out at some iteration - in that case
doesn't work, but the last iteration still has meaning :)
